moves.1... d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. Nc3 Qe5+ 4. Be2:
Till here everything's as in the "book" (well, "my" book). Now, the interesting idea I want to submit is o-o-o, exposing black to Nxf7, winning a rook for a knight but, in the last term, for two minor pieces, since the knight cannot escape and black will take the bishop in f4, threatening to go on with Bxh2 . 
The question is: is this move playable for black? Taking into account that white can answer, for instance, BxBf5 and then leaving a lot of possibilities for black, but all leading to a weak e column. 
This is the reason for I didn't play it, but still I wonder...
moves.10... Ne7: Best answer for white, probably, is 11. BxB, and after NxB... maybe 12. Ne4, or 12. g4!?
moves.11. Re1 O-O-O: I couldn't resist, but probably it would have been better before.
moves.12. Nxf7: It loses two minor pieces for a rook, so it is good for black. But I wanted to go further.
moves.12... Bxf4 13. g3 Nf6: The sacrifice. Is Bd6 better? This is an important question, seeing the rest of the game.
moves.14. Bxf5 Nxf5 15. Nxd8 Rxd8: Now, the rook will press on the d column, and after white takes the bishop, I saw a lot of danger for white.
moves.16. gxf4: He accepted the sacrifice, probably he analyzed it very well. I always trust on my aggressive play, but not always it works...
moves.16... Qxf4: A quality under, but... what an attack!
moves.17. Ne2 Qg4+: If Kf1, Qh3  with more or less the same result, but one move quicker!
moves.18. Ng3 Qh3:
First threat of a mate threat: Ng5. 
If 19. f3, Nxg3, 20. h2xg3, Qxg3 , 21. Kf1, Ng4! (22. fxN, Rf8  and mate, and if 22. Qe2 or Qd2, Nh2  forcing white to lose the queen, and if 22. Re2, Qh1 , 23. Kd2 and Rxd4  wins the queen)!
So he played...
moves.20... Qxh2+ 21. Kf1:
Now, my blindness. I didnt' considered 21. ..., Rf8. 
Now, he can save the knight, winning a second piece. Say 22. Ng3. But then I can take Rxf2, and mate. And if he protects f2 with 23. Re2, Qh1#. 

And if 22. Ne7 , I simply play Kd7, while 22. f3 loses the queen.

It appears as if, even if white has a move, he can't use it to save the game. 

The only choice seems to be 22. Ke2, since after Qxf2 , 23. Kd1, QxQ, 24.QxQ, e6xf5, and despite the quality, black pawns should win but the game is still playable. 

But meybe black has an even better choice: after 22. Ke2, Nxf7... what? The threat is to win the white queen with the knight after the discovered check. 
So let's take a look at the possible moves for white.

A) 23. Rh1 doesn't help after Nxh1 , and now white have to choose between

2) 24. Kd6, Qh3 , and now white again have to choose between 25. Ne3, Nf2 , 26. Ke2, Qf3 , 27. Ke1, QxRa1, winning, or 25. Qe3, QxN , 26. Kd2, Qf2 , 27. QxQ, and black wins because can save the h1 knight both with RxQ or NxQ (28. Rf1, Rf6!).
